[[Northern California]]
United States |damages = $7.5–8 million |intensity = [[Mercalli intensity scale|VIII (''Severe'')]] |pga = 1.3''[[Peak ground acceleration|g]]'' at [[Coyote Dam (Santa Clara County, California)|Coyote Dam]] |tsunami = |landslide = Yes |foreshocks = |aftershocks = |casualties = 21–27 injured }} The '''1984 Morgan Hill earthquake''' (also '''Halls Valley earthquake'''){{cite web|url=http://eps.berkeley.edu/~eps20/intensity/index2.php |title=The Morgan Hill Earthquake of 1984 |publisher=Earthquakes in Your Backyard – And Tsunamis |accessdate=2009-05-29 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hDNIV486?url=http://eps.berkeley.edu/~eps20/intensity/index2.php |archivedate=2009-06-01 |deadurl=no |df= }} occurred on April 24 at {{tooltip|1:15 p.m. local time|21:15 UTC}} in the [[Santa Clara Valley]] of [[Northern California]]. The shock had a moment magnitude of 6.2 and a maximum [[Mercalli intensity scale|Mercalli intensity]] of VIII (''Severe''). The [[epicenter]] was located near [[Mount Hamilton (California)|Mount Hamilton]] in the [[Diablo Range]] of the [[California Coast Ranges]]. Nearby communities (including [[Morgan Hill, California|Morgan Hill]]) sustained serious damage with financial losses of at least [[United States dollar|US$]]7.5 million. ==Earthquake== The earthquake occurred along the [[Calaveras Fault]], with the epicenter {{convert|16|km|mi|sp=us}} northeast of [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], and at a depth of {{convert|8|km|mi|abbr=on}}. The shock was felt in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]] in California's central valley.{{cite journal|last=Toppozada |first=T. R. |url=http://www.johnmartin.com/earthquakes/eqpapers/00000062.htm|title=Morgan Hill Earthquake of April 1984|journal=California Geology|date=1984|volume=37|number=7}} ===Damage=== The earthquake was reported to be felt over an area of {{convert|120000|km2|mi2|sp=us}}. [[Morgan Hill, California|Morgan Hill]] was the worst affected, with a number of mobile homes sliding off foundations, and moderate damage to several [[masonry]] buildings in the city. The communities of [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], [[San Martin, California|San Martin]] and [[Coyote, California|Coyote]] were some areas that experienced minor damage. In [[Santa Clara County]], over 550 buildings were reported to have received at least minor damage. ===Aftershocks=== The outline of aftershocks show that the rupture propagated southeast over a {{convert|25|km|mi|abbr=on}} section of the fault, as far as [[San Martin, California|San Martin]], to the location of the [[1979 Coyote Lake earthquake]]'s mainshock. That event's aftershock zone also stretched to the southeast. ==See also== * [[List of earthquakes in California]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{citation|title=The Morgan Hill, California, Earthquake of April 24, 1984|url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/bul/1639/report.pdf|chapter=The Earthquake and its Aftershocks, April 24 through September 30, 1984|first=R.S.|last=Cockerham|first2=J.P.|last2=Eaton|year=1987|series=U.S. Geological survey Bulletin 1639|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]|page=17}} {{citation|title=ISC-GEM Global Instrumental Earthquake Catalogue (1900–2009)|url=http://www.isc.ac.uk/iscgem/index.php|author=ISC|year=2015|publisher=[[International Seismological Centre]]|series=Version 2.0}} {{citation|title=PAGER-CAT Earthquake Catalog|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/static/lfs/data/pager/catalogs/|author=USGS|date=September 4, 2009|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]|series=Version 2008_06.1}} {{citation|title=Morgan Hill earthquake – Caused record shaking force|url=http://www.conservation.ca.gov/cgs/geologic_hazards/earthquakes/pdfs/Documents/CG_AUG1984.pdf|first=A.|last=Shakal|first2=T. E.|last2=Gay, Jr.|first3=R.|last3=Sherburne |journal=California Geology|page=163 |date=August 1984}} {{citation|last1=Stover|first1=C. W.|last2=Coffman|first2=J. L.|title=Seismicity of the United States, 1568–1989 (Revised)|series=U.S. Geological Survey Professional Paper 1527|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bY0KAQAAIAAJ|year=1993|publisher=[[United States Government Printing Office]]|pages=97, 175}} }} ==External links== * [https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/usp00023vb#general_summary M 6.2 – Northern California] – [[United States Geological Survey]] * {{EQ-isc-link|555788}} {{Earthquakes in 1984}} {{Earthquakes in California}} {{Earthquakes in the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Morgan Hill earthquake}} [[Category:Earthquakes in California|1984]] [[Category:1984 earthquakes]] [[Category:1984 in California]] [[Category:April 1984 events]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox event | title = United Nations Climate Change Conference | image = COP15 Logo.svg | caption = | date = {{start date|2009|12|07|df=y}} –
{{end date|2009|12|18|df=y}} | place = [[Bella Center]], [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] | coordinates = | also known as = COP15 | participants = [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|UNFCCC]] member countries | website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20091213044943/http://www.un.org/wcm/content/site/chronicle/home Special Climate Change Issue] }} [[File:Connie Hedegaard.jpg|thumb|[[Connie Hedegaard]], former president of the UN Climate Change Conference 2009 in Copenhagen (left chair to Danish Prime Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen on 16 December)]] The '''2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference''', commonly known as the '''Copenhagen Summit''', was held at the [[Bella Center]] in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]], between 7 and 18 December. The conference included the 15th Conference of the Parties (COP 15) to the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC) and the 5th Meeting of the Parties (MOP 5) to the [[Kyoto Protocol]]. According to the [[Bali Road Map]], a framework for [[climate change mitigation]] beyond 2012 was to be agreed there.{{cite web|url=http://www.iisd.ca/upcoming/linkagesmeetings.asp?id=5 |title=IISD Reporting Services – Upcoming meetings |publisher=Iisd.ca |date= |accessdate=8 April 2010}} On Friday 18 December, the final day of the conference, international media reported that the climate talks were "in disarray".{{cite web|last=Associated |first=The |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=120160589 |title=UN Chief: Time To Stop Climate Finger-Pointing |publisher=NPR |date=15 December 2009 |accessdate=19 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091119161524/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=120160589 |archivedate=19 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2009/12/obama_in_copenhagen_climate_ch.html |title=Obama in Copenhagen; Climate Talks in Disarray; Urges 'Action Over Inaction' – The Two-Way – Breaking News, Analysis Blog |publisher=NPR |date= |accessdate=19 December 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2009/12/18/copenhagen-last-day.html |title=CBC News – World – Canada part of Copenhagen climate deal |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=27 November 2009 |accessdate=19 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091219201902/http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2009/12/18/copenhagen-last-day.html |archivedate=19 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Media also reported that in lieu of a summit collapse, only a "weak political statement" was anticipated at the conclusion of the conference.{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/last-day-of-copenhagen-summit-hope-fizzling-out/107355-11.html |title=Last day of Copenhagen summit, hope fizzling out |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date= |accessdate=19 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091223014216/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/last-day-of-copenhagen-summit-hope-fizzling-out/107355-11.html |archivedate=23 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite web|author=Lenore Taylor |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/climate-talks-set-for-failure-as-china-dampens-hopes/story-e6frg6nf-1225811570408 |title=Climate talks set for failure as China dampens hopes |publisher=The Australian |date= |accessdate=19 December 2009}} The [[Copenhagen Accord]] was drafted by the United States, China, [[India]], [[Brazil]] and South Africa on 18 December, and judged a "meaningful agreement" by the [[United States government]]. It was "taken note of", but not "adopted", in a debate of all the participating countries the next day, and it was not passed unanimously. The document recognised that climate change is one of the greatest challenges of the present day and that actions should be taken to keep any temperature increases to below 2 °C. The document is not legally binding and does not contain any legally binding commitments for reducing {{co2}} emissions.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/8422307.stm |title=Copenhagen deal: Key points |publisher=BBC News |date=19 December 2009 |accessdate=20 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812064950/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/8422307.stm |archivedate=12 August 2017 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} {{TOC limit|3}} ==Background and lead-up== The conference was preceded by the [[Climate Change: Global Risks, Challenges and Decisions]] scientific conference, which took place in March 2009 and was also held at the Bella Center. The negotiations began to take a new format when in May 2009 UN Secretary General [[Ban Ki-moon]] attended the World Business Summit on Climate Change in Copenhagen, organised by the [[Copenhagen Climate Council]] (COC), where he requested that COC councillors attend New York's Climate Week at the Summit on Climate Change on 22 September and engage with heads of government on the topic of the climate problem.{{citation|author=Tim Flannery |publisher=[[The Monthly]] |date=November 2009 |title=Copenhagen and Beyond: Conference Bound |url=http://www.themonthly.com.au/monthly-essays-tim-flannery-copenhagen-and-beyond-conference-bound-2110 |accessdate=8 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100506043909/http://www.themonthly.com.au/monthly-essays-tim-flannery-copenhagen-and-beyond-conference-bound-2110 |archivedate=6 May 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} ==Negotiating position of the European Union== On 28 January 2009, the [[European Commission]] released a position paper, "Towards a comprehensive climate agreement in Copenhagen."{{cite press release|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/09/34&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en |title=Questions and Answers on the Communication Towards a comprehensive climate change agreement in Copenhagen |publisher=European Union |date=28 January 2009 |accessdate=14 February 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100218075503/http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO%2F09%2F34&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en |archivedate=18 February 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The position paper "addresses three key challenges: targets and actions; financing [of "low-carbon development and adaptation"]; and building an effective [[global carbon market]]".{{cite web |url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/climat/pdf/future_action/communication.pdf |title=Towards a comprehensive climate agreement in Copenhagen |publisher=European Union| accessdate= 8 April 2010}} Leading by example, the European Union had committed to implementing binding legislation, even without a satisfactory deal in Copenhagen. Last December, the European Union revised its carbon allowances system called the [[European Union Emission Trading Scheme|Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS)]] designed for the post-Kyoto period (after 2013). This new stage of the system aims at further reducing greenhouse gases emitted in Europe in a binding way and at showing the commitments the EU had already done before the Copenhagen meeting. To avoid carbon leakage—relocation of companies in other regions not complying with similar legislation—the EU Commission will foresee that sectors exposed to international competition, should be granted some free allocations of CO2 emissions provided that they are at least at the same level of a benchmark. Other sectors should buy such credits on an international market. Energy intensive industries in Europe have advocated for this benchmark system in order to keep funds in investment capacities for low carbon products rather than for speculations.{{cite web|author= |url=//www.youtube.com/watch?v=b1kf_axslfk |title=Jumping the climate change hurdle |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=9 December 2009}} The European chemical industry claims here the need to be closer to the needs of citizens in a sustainable way. To comply with such commitments for a [[low-carbon economy]], this requires competitiveness and innovations.{{cite web|author= |url=//www.youtube.com/watch?v=bpmXY0R7RLQ |title=Building Blocks for Climate Change Solutions |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=9 December 2009}} The French Minister for Ecology [[Jean-Louis Borloo]] pushes the creation of the [[Global Environment Organisation]] as France's main institutional contribution, to offer a powerful alternative to the [[United Nations Environment Programme|UNEP]]. ==Official pre-Copenhagen negotiation meetings== A draft negotiating text{{cite web|url=http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2009/awglca6/eng/08.pdf |format=PDF |title=Negotiating text |publisher=United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change |page=53 |language=English |accessdate=15 June 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611193811/http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2009/awglca6/eng/08.pdf |archivedate=11 June 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2009/awglca7/eng/inf02.pdf |format=PDF |title=Negotiating text |publisher=United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change |page=181 |language=English |accessdate=15 September 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007065138/http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2009/awglca7/eng/inf02.pdf |archivedate=7 October 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} for finalisation at Copenhagen was publicly released. It was discussed at a series of meetings before Copenhagen. ===Bonn – second negotiating meeting=== Delegates from 183 countries met in [[Bonn]] from 1 to 12 June 2009. The purpose was to discuss key negotiating texts. These served as the basis for the international climate change agreement at Copenhagen. At the conclusion the Ad Hoc Working Group under the Kyoto Protocol ([[AWG-KP]]) negotiating group was still far away from the emission reduction range that has been set out by science to [[Avoiding dangerous climate change|avoid the worst ravages of climate change]]: a minus 25% to minus 40% reduction below 1990 levels by 2020. The AWG-KP still needs to decide on the aggregate emission reduction target for industrialised countries, along with individual targets for each country. Progress was made in gaining clarification of the issues of concern to parties and including these concerns in the updated draft of the negotiating text.{{cite web|url=http://unfccc.int/files/press/news_room/press_releases_and_advisories/application/pdf/091206_closing_pr_sb30.pdf|format=PDF|title=Progress Made in Negotiations for Ambitious and Effective Copenhagen Deal at Bonn UNFCCC Meeting|date=12 June 2009|work=Press Release|publisher=UNFCCC/CCNUCC|page=2|accessdate=15 June 2009}} ===Seventh session=== ====Bangkok==== The first part of the seventh session of the AWG-LCA was held in Bangkok, Thailand, from Monday, 28 September until 9 October, at the [[United Nations Conference Centre (Bangkok)|United Nations Conference Centre]] (UNCC) of the [[United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific]] (UNESCAP), [[Bangkok]], Thailand.{{cite web|url=http://unfccc.int/meetings/intersessional/bangkok_09/items/4967.php |title=Bangkok Climate Change Talks – 2009 |publisher=United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change |accessdate=7 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091109222317/http://unfccc.int/meetings/intersessional/bangkok_09/items/4967.php |archivedate=9 November 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} ====Barcelona==== The resumed session was held in [[Barcelona, Spain]], from 2 to 6 November 2009. Thereafter, the AWG-LCA met to conclude its work at its eighth session, concurrently with the fifteenth session of the Conference of the Parties which opened in Copenhagen on 7 December 2009. ===Listing of proposed actions=== {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; font-size:95%;" |+ Proposed changes in absolute emissions |- ! Scotland | −50% to −75% (per GDP) |} During the conference some countries stated what actions they were proposing to take if a binding agreement was achieved. In the end, no such agreement was reached and the actions will instead be debated in 2010. Listing by country or political union. Sections in alphabetic order, table according to higher objectives. ====Australia==== To cut [[carbon accounting|carbon]] emissions by 25% below 2000 levels by 2020 if the world agrees to an ambitious global deal to stabilise levels of [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|CO2e]] to 450 [[parts per million|ppm]] or lower.{{Citation|author1=Kevin Rudd |author2=Penny Wong |author3=Wayne Swan |title=A new target for reducing Australia's carbon pollution |publisher=[[Department of Climate Change]] |date=4 May 2009 |url=http://www.climatechange.gov.au/~/media/Files/minister/wong/2009/media-releases/May/mr20090504c.ashx |accessdate=8 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027003859/http://climatechange.gov.au/~/media/Files/minister/wong/2009/media-releases/May/mr20090504c.ashx |archivedate=27 October 2009 }}{{cite news|url=http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/pdf/science/earth/20091218_CLIMATE_TEXT.pdf|title=Copenhagen Accord|website=The New York Times|date=18 December 2009| accessdate= 8 April 2010}} [[File:Alston Koch at the 2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Copenhagen.jpg|thumb|238px|[[Alston Koch]] discusses Climate Change at the ''2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference''.]] To cut carbon emissions by 15% below 2000 levels by 2020 if there is an agreement where major developing economies commit to substantially restrain emissions and advanced economies take on commitments comparable to Australia.{{Citation|url=http://unfccc.int/files/kyoto_protocol/application/pdf/jointsubmission290409.pdf|authors=Australia, Belarus, Canada, EU, Iceland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, Russia, Switzerland, Ukraine|publisher=UNFCCC|title=Joint submission: Information relating to possible quantified emissions limitation and reduction objectives as submitted by Parties|date=| accessdate= 8 April 2010}} To cut carbon emissions by 5% below 2000 levels by 2020 unconditionally. It is clearly stated in proceedings from the [[Australian Senate]]{{Citation |author=[[Australian Labor Party]] |title=Carbon Pollution Reduction Scheme Bill 2009 (No. 2) |date=22 October 2009 |publisher=Hansard of the [[Australian Parliament]] |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/library/pubs/bd/2009-10/10bd059.htm |accessdate=8 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505131725/http://www.aph.gov.au/library/pubs/bd/2009-10/10bd059.htm |archivedate=5 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} and policy statements from the government{{Citation|author1=Kevin Rudd |author2=Penny Wong |author3=Wayne Swan |title=Carbon Pollution Reduction Scheme: Australia's Low Pollution Future|date=15 December 2008|publisher=[[Department of Climate Change]]|page=7|url=http://www.climatechange.gov.au/publications/cprs/white-paper/~/media/publications/white-paper/V100eExecutiveSummary-pdf.ashx| accessdate= 8 April 2010}}{{Citation|author1=Kevin Rudd |author2=Penny Wong |author3=Wayne Swan |title=Details of Proposed CPRS changes|date=24 November 2009|publisher=Australian Government [[Department of Climate Change]]|url=http://www.climatechange.gov.au/~/media/publications/cprs/CPRS_ESAS/091124oppnofferpdf.ashx| accessdate= 8 April 2010}} that the Australian emission reductions include [[land use, land-use change and forestry]] (LULUCF) with the form of inclusion remaining undecided and whilst acknowledging that they are subject to the forming of accounting guidelines from this Copenhagen conference. In contention is the Australian Government's preference for the removal of non-human induced [[LULUCF]] emissions – and perhaps their abatement – from the account, such as from [[lightning]] induced [[bushfires]] and the subsequent natural carbon sequestering regrowth.{{Citation|title=PM and Abbott are in the same boat|publisher=News Corporation|author=Lenore Taylor|date=15 December 2009|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/politics/pm-and-abbott-are-in-the-same-boat/story-e6frgczf-1225810403852| accessdate= 8 April 2010}} Using [[Flexible Mechanisms|Kyoto accounting guidelines]], these proposals are equivalent to an emissions cut of 24%, 14% and 4% below 1990 levels by 2020 respectively. for the establishment of infrastructure for [[electric vehicle]]s. At this international conference, 250 high-ranking representatives from industry, science, politics and non-government organizations discussed solutions for future road transportation under the motto of "Sustainable Mobility– United Nations Climate Change Conference 2009|the Post-2012 {{CO2}} Agenda".{{cite web |url=http://climate-l.org/2008/07/11/unep-and-daimler-call-for-infrastructure-for-electric-and-fuel-cell-vehicles/#more-1003 |title=UNEP and Daimler Call for Infrastructure for Electric and Fuel-cell Vehicles |publisher=Climate-L.org |date=4 July 2008 |accessdate=9 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20091213000040/http://climate-l.org/2008/07/11/unep-and-daimler-call-for-infrastructure-for-electric-and-fuel-cell-vehicles/#more-1003 |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} ====Technology Action Programs==== Technology Action Programs (TAPs) have been proposed as a means for organizing future technology efforts under the UNFCCC. By creating programs for a set of adaptation and mitigation technologies, the UNFCCC would send clear signals to the private and finance sector, governments, research institutions as well as citizens of the world looking for solutions to the climate problem. Potential focus areas for TAPs include early warning systems, expansion of [[halophyte|salinity-tolerant]] crops, electric vehicles, wind and solar energy, efficient energy grid systems, and other technologies.http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2008/smsn/ngo/071.pdf Technology roadmaps will address barriers to technology transfer, cooperative actions on technologies and key economic sectors, and support implementation of Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs)http://unfccc.int/files/kyoto_protocol/application/pdf/india100209b.pdf and National Adaptation Programmes of Action (NAPAs).{{cite web|url=http://unfccc.int/national_reports/napa/items/2719.php |title=National Adaptation Programmes of Action (NAPAs) |publisher=Unfccc.int |date= |accessdate=9 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091110012850/http://unfccc.int/national_reports/napa/items/2719.php |archivedate=10 November 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} ====Side Event on Technology Transfer==== The United Nations Industrial Development Organisation ([[UNIDO]]) and the Department of Economic and Social Affairs ([[UNDESA]]) have been assigned the task of co-convening a process to support UN system-wide coherence and international cooperation on [[climate change-related technology]] development and transfer. This COP15 Side Event will feature statements and input from the heads of UNDESA, [[UNDP]], [[Global Environment Facility|GEF]], [[WIPO]], UNIDO, [[UNEP]], [[IRENA]] as well as the [[UN Foundation]].
